prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Eta Carina B7: Mapping CO 3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO J=3-2 at ~100 mas resolution (7 x better than VLT/XShooter mapping of H2 and equal to HST imagery of dust-scattered starlight), will provide us with the latitudinal distribution of gas in each of the main velocity components revealed by the HIFI and APEX observations. In conjunction with J=2-1, excitation analysis will yield approximate estimates of the rotation temperatures of the emitting gas. As the upper energy levels are close for the two line, combining the data with our HIFI spectra (up to J=8-7) will yield accurate excitation temperatures and column densities and thus CO/H2 abundances in each velocity component and thus in different regions of the nebula mapped in the lower transitions. The characteristic scale of both the emission lines and the continuum is less than 1-2 arcsec. As demonstrated by our H2 3D maps, the shell structures rapidly shift in velocity and spatial components. Within the central 1.5 arcsec diameter of eta Car, multiple wind-wind structures produced by periastron passages over the last 20 years have been mapped at 0.1 arcsec resolution by HST/STIS. These fossil wind structures are best seen in [Fe III], [Fe II], [Ar III] and the Balmer series emission as discrete structures with velocities ranging from -420 to +350 km/s The same hydrogen line profile is seen in Herschel PACS and HIFI spectra. Based upon observations with HST/STIS, the emissions will shift in velocity on a scale of 400 km/s in less than 0.5 arcsec. As we will map with channels of the largest velocity width, 30 km/s in B7 at 1875 MHz baseband width, we will obtain small-scale continuum maps at the same time in addition to maps of H30alpha in B6. We will thus be able to separate the warm dust continuum from the recombination continuum arising from ionized regions by comparison of the continuum maps to the H30alpha measures. This ALMA mapping will dramatically improve our understanding of the conditions supporting molecule and dust survival around an extremely massive star in a near-supernova stage. Virtually all emission anticipated from the CO and the H recombination lines, and possibly the continuum, is expected to have spatial variations of 1 arcsec or less and with velocities as much as 100 to 500 km/s.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: Observation to be scheduled about one year after the low state observation for CO6-5

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The limiting spectral line sensitivity, requested bandwidth and estimated continuum strength are due solely to the expected intensities derived for the CO transitions and what the anticipated continuum flux density will be at the position of the CO emission. The H alpha/beta lines are known to be strong and easily detected with ALMA at >80 Jy peak flux on top of the very bright (~40 Jy) and compact (~1") emission region (Abraham et al. 2014) . What is not well known and is the prime investigation from this study is the distribution and morphology of the molecular gas toward this source, the overall structure of the "fast" and "slow" outflows and amount of continuum emission in these more extend components. As such the predicted CO line intensity will be underestimated and the continuum emission easily overestimated which leads to predicted high dynamic range value computed by the OT. In reality, the expected dynamic range should be much closer to approved Cycle 3 value of 100.
The 12CO J=3-2 and 2-1 line strengths have been estimated using an excitation analysis of the spatially unresolved J=3-2 and 4-3 observed with APEX/CHAMP+ (Loinard et al. 2013) and J=5-4 through 8-7 with Herschel/HIFI (Gull et al.). CO J=6-5 was observed with both instruments, and used to check consistency. The radiative transfer was done with Radex (van der Tak et al 2007)in LTE. Emitting source sizes have been approximated by association of the velocity components of the observed CO profiles to kinematic features of the Homunculus from H2 and [FeII/III] observations (see Science Justification), and the intensities scaled for beam dilution effects between HIFI, APEX, and ALMA.
The overall spatial structure of this source is still largely unknown at these wavelengths and largely inferred only by spectral line observations of "fast" CO (-500 to +500 km/s) and "slow" (-70 to + 70 km/s) features. In order to detect both the slow and fast molecular gas components simultaneously with as much signal-to-noise per channel as possible, we sacrificed spectral resolution for bandwidth. We will accept a 2-3 channels across our spectral feature in order to spatial resolve the structure of the molecular emission components. Once we have these initial detections, high spectral resolution observations will be warranted to try and determine any smaller scale, low velocity structure within the bulk molecular flow.
Finally, there is still the possibility during Phase 2 to set up an additional continuum window in the lower sideband. This will be discussed with the P2G member as part of the "best practices" for setting up ALMA observations to ease in the calibration process.
See the above explanation. We fully acknowledge that the lines would not be fully resolved at the requested resolution.

The Homunculus of Eta Carina is very clumpy as seen at the HST spatial resolution of 0.1" diffractive limit. At that spatial resolution and spectral resolving power of ~10000 (30 km/s) there is a relatively uniform curvature of the Homunculus due to the geometry of the bipolar shell. It is expected that at the 0.09" spatial resolution (and 1.4" LAS) requested for these observations (configuration C36-6 from Chapter 7 of the ALMA technical handbook), we will see CO emission varying across the bipolar shell due to clumping and curvature, especially at the edges where limb brightening would occur. The multiple pointings are necessary to encompass the entirety of the outflows and to determine the largest angular extent of the emission from the central point of origin.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Eta Carina B6: Mapping CO 2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO J=2-1 at ~100 mas resolution (7 x better than VLT/XShooter mapping of H2 and equal to HST imagery of dust-scattered starlight), will provide us with the latitudinal distribution of gas in each of the main velocity components revealed by the HIFI and APEX observations. In conjunction with J=3-3, excitation analysis will yield approximate estimates of the rotation temperatures of the emitting gas. As the upper energy levels are close for the two line, combining the data with our HIFI spectra (up to J=8-7) will yield accurate excitation temperatures and column densities and thus CO/H2 abundances in each velocity component and thus in different regions of the nebula mapped in the lower transitions. The characteristic scale of both the emission lines and the continuum is less than 1-2 arcsec. As demonstrated by our H2 3D maps, the shell structures rapidly shift in velocity and spatial components. Within the central 1.5 arcsec diameter of eta Car, multiple wind-wind structures produced by periastron passages over the last 20 years have been mapped at 0.1 arcsec resolution by HST/STIS. These fossil wind structures are best seen in [Fe III], [Fe II], [Ar III] and the Balmer series emission as discrete structures with velocities ranging from -420 to +350 km/s The same hydrogen line profile is seen in Herschel PACS and HIFI spectra, and thus we include H30alpha in the same sideband, separated by 1.4 GHz. Based upon observations with HST/STIS, the emissions will shift in velocity on a scale of 400 km/s in less than 0.5 arcsec. As we will map with channels of the largest velocity width, 40 km/s in B6 at 1875 MHz baseband width, we will obtain small-scale continuum maps at the same time in addition to maps of H30alpha in B6. We will thus be able to separate the warm dust continuum from the recombination continuum arising from ionized regions by comparison of the continuum maps to the H30alpha measures. This ALMA mapping will dramatically improve our understanding of the conditions supporting molecule and dust survival around an extremely massive star in a near-supernova stage. Virtually all emission anticipated from the CO and the H recombination lines, and possibly the continuum, is expected to have spatial variations of 1 arcsec or less and with velocities as much as 100 to 500 km/s.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: Observation to be scheduled about one year after the low state observation for CO6-5

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The limiting spectral line sensitivity, requested bandwidth and estimated continuum strength are due solely to the expected intensities derived for the CO transitions and what the anticipated continuum flux density will be at the position of the CO emission. The H alpha/beta lines are known to be strong and easily detected with ALMA at >80 Jy peak flux on top of the very bright (~40 Jy) and compact (~1") emission region (Abraham et al. 2014) . What is not well known and is the prime investigation from this study is the distribution and morphology of the molecular gas toward this source, the overall structure of the "fast" and "slow" outflows and amount of continuum emission in these more extend components. As such the predicted CO line intensity will be underestimated and the continuum emission easily overestimated which leads to predicted high dynamic range value computed by the OT. In reality, the expected dynamic range should be much closer to approved Cycle 3 value of 100.
The 12CO J=3-2 and 2-1 line strengths have been estimated using an excitation analysis of the spatially unresolved J=3-2 and 4-3 observed with APEX/CHAMP+ (Loinard et al. 2013) and J=5-4 through 8-7 with Herschel/HIFI (Gull et al.). CO J=6-5 was observed with both instruments, and used to check consistency. The radiative transfer was done with Radex (van der Tak et al 2007) in LTE. Emitting source sizes have been approximated by association of the velocity components of the observed CO profiles to kinematic features of the Homunculus from H2 and [FeII/III] observations (see Science Justification), and the intensities scaled for beam dilution effects between HIFI, APEX, and ALMA.
The overall spatial structure of this source is still largely unknown at these wavelengths and largely inferred only by spectral line observations of "fast" CO (-500 to +500 km/s) and "slow" (-70 to + 70 km/s) features. In order to detect both the slow and fast molecular gas components simultaneously with as much signal-to-noise per channel as possible, we sacrificed spectral resolution for bandwidth. We will accept a 2-3 channels across our spectral feature in order to spatial resolve the structure of the molecular emission components. Once we have these initial detections, high spectral resolution observations will be warranted to try and determine any smaller scale, low velocity structure within the bulk molecular flow.
Finally, there is still the possibility during Phase 2 to set up an additional continuum window in the lower sideband. This will be discussed with the P2G member as part of the "best practices" for setting up ALMA observations to ease in the calibration process.
See the above explanation. We fully acknowledge that the lines would not be fully resolved at the requested resolution.

The Homunculus of Eta Carina is very clumpy as seen at the HST spatial resolution of 0.1" diffractive limit. At that spatial resolution and spectral resolving power of ~10000 (30 km/s) there is a relatively uniform curvature of the Homunculus due to the geometry of the bipolar shell. It is expected that at the 0.13" spatial resolution (and 2.1" LAS) requested for these observations (configuration C36-6 from Chapter 7 of the ALMA technical handbook), we will see CO emission varying across the bipolar shell due to clumping and curvature, especially at the edges where limb brightening would occur. The multiple pointings are necessary to encompass the entirety of the outflows and to determine the largest angular extent of the emission from the central point of origin.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We will use ALMA to map CO, H recombination transitions, and continuum throughout the 14"x20" massive, chemically enriched, dusty bipolar Homunculus Nebula around the super-luminous star Eta Carina to understand the formation and survival of molecules and dust in the harsh environment of a very luminous hot massive star. ALMA will spatially resolve the Homunculus at a scale of 0.1" (=230 AU) and provide position-velocity data to construct detailed 3-D maps. These maps will be directly compared to our 3-D maps of H2 which revealed structures that are surprisingly different from the bipolar dust structures. The ALMA maps will also be compared to our STIS 3-D maps in [FeII] and [FeIII] to relate the formation of molecules and dust to the large scale stellar wind structures. Our proposed ALMA observations will constrain the survivability of molecules and dust in this harsh radiative environment and around other luminous stellar eruptions, and provide an analog to the survival of the molecules and dust produced by the first generation of massive stars. No other object allows for a similar analysis due to the youth, the proximity, and the brightness of the Homunculus nebula.
